715838f-a.text: 2-4 Avenue "A", east side, at East Houston Street. The 4-story house and its 2-story adjunct comprise one unit extending from Avenue "A" to Norfolk Street in the center of East Houston Street. July V, 1929. P. L. Sperr.

719699f-a.text:
178-184 Essex Street, adjoining, and at the S.E. corner of Houston Street. The view also shows Avenue A, west side, north of Houston Street. Public School Number 13 is at the right.

719699f-a.folder: Essex Street & Houston Street, Manhattan, NY

719499f-a.text:
(1)
East Houston Street, north side, vest from Ave. "A." Also shown is 1-3 Ave. "A" (5-story building at apex), west side, between East Houston and East 1st (extreme right) Streets. These houses were later demolished to make room for the construction of the Independent Subway System (Eighth Ave. Subway). IIn the foreground is shown the entrance to B. S.
No. 13.
December 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A portion of the same prior to the demolition shown in No. 1. This view is westward from No. 210, (shown on the extreme right), as seen from Ludlow Street. Note the Second Ave. Elevated Line on Allen Street.
July 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A view northward through clearance shown in No. 1. Appearing across same are buildings on the north side of East 1st Street, between First Ave. (left, not shown) and Ave. A (right, not shown). This view
is as seen north from Ludlow Street.
December 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

732969f-a.title: Social conditions - Unemployed [unemployment market.]
732969f-a.text:
Social Conditions--Unemployed: An unemployment market at Houston and Essex Streets, Manhattan, where the unemployed hire themselves out for odd jobs.
MAY BE REPRODUCED  Early 1930's
732969f-a.folder: Houston Street and Essex Street, Manhattan, N.Y.

710828f-b.text:
(1)
1st Street, north side, between Avenue A and First Avenue, seen from the clearing at the S.E. corner of Houston and Ludlow Streets. The small structure is a new Synagogue and the spire in the background belongs to St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Church, on 2nd Street.
The building in the right foreground is 222 East Houston Street. That and four more houses not shown in the picture are all that remains of a long triangular block between Houston and 1st Streets. The rest of the buildings have been demolished in constructing the new subway, as have the houses that stood on the clearing in the foreground.
Neg: 2911 March 13, 1932
P.L. Sperr.

(2)
A closer and more restricted view of the same scene, seen from the S.W. corner of Ludlow and Houston Streets. The clearing is for a Brooklyn line of the city-owned Eighth Avenue subway. In No. 2 the tower with the cross is part of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Redeemer at 161 East 3rd Street.
February 23, 1932
P.L. Sperr.
